section1.title: 0.1 Definition of AI
section1.content1:
There are four approaches to developing AI. 
 
- The cognitive modelling approach. 
 
- The 'Law of Thought' approach 
 
- The Turing Test approach
 
- The Rational Agent approach
section1.content2: These approaches frame the way that AI can be defined as.

section2.title: 02. Difference between AI, ML and DL
section2.content1:
AI: Artifical Intelligence 
 Any technique that enables computers to mimic human intelligence, using logic, if-then rules, inference and reasoning and machine learning. 
 
 ML: Machine Learning 
 A subset of AI that enables machines to improve at tasks with experience.
section2.content2:
DL: Deep Learning 
 A subset of machine learning composed of algorithms that permit software to train itself to perform tasks like speech recognition and image processing, by exposing multilayered neural networks to vast amounts of data.

section3.title: 03. What concepts/ problem types are there?
section3.content1:
These problems will be explored further in the next section: 
 
- Navigational Search Problems
 
- Simple Optimisation Problem 
 
- Simple Classification and Regression Problems 
 
- Neural Network Models
section3.content2:
- Markov Decision Process for Reinforcement Learning
 
- Reinforcement Learning 
 
- Convolutional Neural Networks for Image Classification 
 
- Natural Language Processing

section1.title: 01. Navigational Search and Simple Optimisation Problems
section1.content1:
Navigational Search Problems (Uninformed/ Informed) 

 - Breadth First Search 

 - Depth First Search 

 - Uniform Cost Search 

 - Greedy Best First Search 

 - A-star Search
section1.content2:
Simple Optimisation Problems: 

 - Hill Climbing 

 - Simulated Annealing 

 - Genetic Algorithm

section2.title: 02. Classification, Regression and Neural Network Problems
section2.content1:
Simple Classification and Regression Problems: 

 - Decision tree learning 

 - Random Forest 

 - Support vector machine learning 

 - Linear regression/ logistic regression 

 - K-nearest neighbours learning
section2.content2:
Neural Network Models: 

 - Perceptron Model: binary 

 - Multilayer perceptron / Forward neural networks (FNN): binary or multi-class or regression problems. They can have single or multiple output. 

 - Recurrent neural network (RNN): time series prediction 

 - Long-term short memory (LSTM): time series prediction

section3.title: 03. MDP and Reinforcement Learning
section3.content1:
Markov Decision Process (MDP) for Reinforcement Learning Algorithms:
 
 - Value Iteration: Utility Value 

 - Policy Iteration: Optimal Policy
section3.content2:
Reinforcement Learning: 

 Passive RL algorithms include: 
 - Direct Utility Estimation (DUE) 
 - Adaptative dynamic programming (ADP) 
 - Temporal Difference (TD) 
 
 Active RL algorithm includes: 
 - Q-Learning

section4.title: 04. CNN and NLP
section4.content1:
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for Image Classification: 

 - Self-defined CNN 

 - AlexNet 

 - Yolo Detection
section4.content2:
Natural Language Processing (NLP): 

 1. Tokenisation 

 2. Extract n-grams from a given corpus 

 3. Word 2 vec 

 4. Sentiment Analysis 

 Sentiment Analysis techniques include: 
 - Naive Bayes 
 - LR 
 - SVM 
 - Decision Trees 
 - LSTM 
 - Pretrained Transformers.
